that makes him a great actor this

human beings use 100% of their brain
capacity the brain is a highly efficient
energy demanding organ that gets fully
utilized and even though it is at full
capacity being used it suffers from a
problem of information overload there's
far too much in the environment than it
can fully process so to solve this
problem of overload evolution devised a
solution which is the brains attention
system attention allows us to notice
select and direct the brains
computational resources to a subset of
all that's available we can think of
attention as the leader of the brain
wherever attention goes the rest of the
brain follows in some sense it's your
brains boss and over the last 15 years
I've been studying the human brains
attention system in all of our studies
I've been very interested in one
question if it is indeed the case that
our attention is the brains boss is it a
good boss does it actually guide us well
and to dig in on this big question I
wanted to know three things first how
does attention control our perception
second why does it fail us often leaving
us feeling foggy and distracted and
third can we do anything about this
fogginess can we train our brain to pay

stable attention in the work that we we
do in our lives so I wanted to give you
a brief glimpse into how we're gonna
look at this a very poignant example of
how our attention ends up getting
utilized and I want to do it using the
example of somebody that I know quite
well
he ends up being part of a very large
group of people that we work with for
whom attention is a matter of life and

is the story of a marine captain captain
Jeff Davis and the scene that I'm going
to share with you as you can see is not
about his time in the battlefield he was
actually on a bridge in Florida but
instead of looking at the scenery around
him seeing the beautiful vistas and
noticing the cool ocean breezes he was
driving fast and contemplating driving

not to do so you see he just returned

thousands of miles away
he was gripped with suffering his mind
was worried and preoccupied and had

leader knew that he wasn't the only one

the year 2008 he partnered with me in a
the first-of-its-kind project that

before I tell you about what mindfulness

I think it's important to understand how
attention works in the brain so what we
do in the laboratory is that many of our
studies of attention involve brainwave
recordings in these brainwave recordings
people were finally looking caps that
are sort of like swimming caps that have
electrodes embedded in them these
electrodes pick up the ongoing brain
electrical activity and they do it with
millisecond temporal precision so we can
see these small yet detectable voltage
fluctuations over time and doing this we
can very precisely plot the timing of
the brains activity about a hundred and
seventy milliseconds after we've shown
our research participants a face on the
screen
a very reliable detectable brain
signature it happens right at the back
of the scalp above the regions of the
brain that are involved in face
processing now this happens so reliably
and so on cue as the brains face
detector that we've even given this
brain wave component a name we call it
the n170 component and we use this
component in many of our studies it
allows us to see the impact that
attention may have on our perception so
I'm going to give you a sense of the
kind of experiments that we actually do
in the lab we would show participants
images like this one you should see a
face and a scene overlaid on each other
and what we do is we ask our
participants as they're viewing a series
of these types of overlaid images to do
something with their attention on some

to the face and to make sure they're

to be male or female on other trials we

was it indoor or outdoor and in this way
we can manipulate attention and confirm
that the participants were actually
doing what we said our hypotheses about
attention were as follows if attention
is indeed doing his job and affecting

that when we direct attention to the

right it's easier to see but when we

scene information so what we wanted to
do is look at this brainwave component
of face detection the n170 and see if it
changed at all as a function of where
our participants were paying attention
to the scene or the face and here's what
we found we found that when they paid
attention to the face the n170 was
larger and when they paid attention to
the scene as you can see in red it was
smaller and that gap you see between the
blue and red lines is pretty powerful
what it tells us is that attention which
is really the only thing that changed
since the images they viewed were
identical in both cases attention
changes perception and it does so
very fast within 170 milliseconds of
actually seeing a face in our follow-up

that's indeed what we found if we

attention shrinks its power diminishes
so in some of our other studies we

actually bad news that stress does this

what if we don't need external

people happily generate all kinds of

even though it's quite plain to see but

here what happens when people have

and what we found was that very similar

when this mind wandering happens it can

at the metaphor of a music player we see

to reflect on events that have already

most times without our awareness even if
we want to be paying attention think of
just the last time we're trying to read

with no idea what the words were saying
right this happens to us and when this
happens when we mind wander without an
ax
that we're doing it there are
consequences we make errors we miss

have difficulty making decisions what's
worse is when we experience stress when
we're in a moment of overwhelm
we don't just reflect on the past when

under stress we fast-forward the mind
not just a productively plan but we end

about events that haven't happened yet

okay
mind wandering is happening a lot often
it happens without our awareness and
under stress it's even worse we mind

is there anything we can possibly do

and Montand wandering mind is a mindful
one mindfulness has to do with paying
attention to our present moment
experience with awareness and without
any kind of emotional reactivity of
what's happening it's about keeping that
button right on play to experience the
moment-to-moment
unfolding of our lives and mindfulness
is not just a concept it's more like

mode of being to have any benefits and a
lot of the work that we're doing we're
offering people programs that give our
participants a suite of exercises that
they should do daily in order to
cultivate more moments of mindfulness in

that we work with high-stress groups
like I said soldiers medical
professionals for them is that we know
that mind-wandering can be really dire
so we want to make sure we offer them
very accessible Lowe time constraints to

we can do is track to see what happens
not just in their regular lives but when

circumstances that they may have
why do we want to do this well we wanted
for example give it to students right
around final-season or we want to give

season or soldiers and Marines while
they're deploying why is that because
those are the moments that in which
their attention is most likely to be
vulnerable because of stress and
mind-wandering and those are also the
moments in which we want their attention
to be in peak shape so they can perform
well so what we do in our research is we
have them take a series of attention
tests so we track their attention at the

interval and then two months later we
track them again and we want to see if
there's a difference is there any
benefit of offering them mindfulness
training can we protect against the
lapse is an attention that might arise
over high stress so here's what we find
over a high stress interval
unfortunately the reality is if we don't
do anything at all attention declines
people are worse at the end of this high
stress interval than before but if we
offer mindfulness training we can
protect against this they stay stable
even though just like the other groups
they were experiencing high stress and
perhaps even more impressive is that if
people take our training programs over
let's say eight weeks and they fully

exercises that allow them to learn how
to be in a present moment in the present
moment well they actually get better
over time even though they're in high
stress and this last point is actually
important to realize because it suggests
to us is that mindfulness exercises are
very much like physical exercise if you
don't do it you don't benefit but if you
do engage in mindfulness practice the
more you do the more you benefit and I
want to just bring it back to captain
Jeff Davis as I mentioned to you at the

did in offering mindfulness training and
they showed this exact pattern which was
very heartening we had offered them the

after this deployment there were much
more press
they were discerning they were not as
reactive and in some case they were

other he said in many ways he felt that

growth to us this was very compelling
and it ended up that captain Davis and I
you know this was about a decade ago in
2008 we've kept in touch all these years
and he himself has gone on to continue

way he was promoted to major he actually
then ended up retiring from the Marine

and through all of these challenges and

fate would have it just a few months ago
captain Davis suffered a massive heart

want to tell you something I know that
the doctors who worked on me they saved

the presence of mind I had to stop the

leader and died and saved his life so I
